Award.AwardTitle: Discovery and analysis of Aphelidea and Rozella species of the Cryptomycota phylum
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cryptomycota is a recently discovered phylum of organisms that parasitize algae and fungi hosts. As first described, the Cryptomycota included only two organisms of known morphologies and over 40 other organisms known only from DNA sequences collected from freshwater, sediments and soils, which suggested that this enigmatic group might be genetically as diverse as the whole Kingdom Fungi. New molecular techniques have the power to identify novel organisms such as these in the environment but the challenge to link the DNA data with physical organisms remains. This project puts a face on these environmental molecular markers with the isolation, culture and structural and molecular characterization of these seemingly ubiquitous, but poorly known, organisms. The known organisms have characteristics of fungi and protists and the project will resolve the intriguing question whether these parasites are fungi or protists. Because Cryptomycota have recently been identified as primary pests of commercially grown algae for production of biofuel, food and pharmaceuticals, this research is important to development of protection strategies for these industries. With greater knowledge of Cryptomycota diversity, their environmental impacts on host populations, food webs, and sustainability of life in nature can be explored. This project will train graduate students and undergraduate students in methods to collect, observe, and describe Cryptomycota, providing the next generation of experts.

This project aims to discover and culture described and new species of Cryptomycota, characterizing them with developmental, ultrastructural and molecular features. Algal and zoosporic fungal hosts of Cryptomycota will be collected from diverse habitats in eastern and southern United States. It is hypothesized that motile cells of Cryptomycota harbor ultrastructural architectural patterns in organellar arrangements which reflect evolutionary relationships. Analyses of seven genes will reveal phylogenetic relationships and permit mapping of host, nutritional and ultrastructural character state evolution, thereby generating hypotheses about early fungal evolution and divergence of Cryptomycota from protists and animals. A Cryptomycota website will include images, taxonomic summaries, interactive identification keys, and applications of ultrastructural and molecular characters in phylogenetic analyses, making this group more tractable for future studies. The research is transformative because cultures of Cryptomycota will be available to the community for even more extensive research. Undergraduate students in freshman biology will be given an authentic research experience making field collections of host organisms, screening for presence of Cryptomycota endoparasites, and characterizing with gene sequences, stimulating students' interest in research careers in biodiversity and conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project is to discover and characterize the poorly known organisms, Aphelidea and Rozella, using morphological, ultrastructural, and molecular techniques. Three groups of plasmodial endoparasites, once classified in different kingdoms, are now viewed as related and placed in a superphylum, Opisthosporidia: (1) Cryptomycota, including Rozella, as endoparasites of chytrid fungi and oomycetes; (2) Aphelidea as endoparasites of algae; and (3) Microsporidia as endoparasites of animal cells. As a sister clade to the traditionally recognized Kingdom Fungi and to the protistan-like nucleriids, these organisms are of broad interest because of their parasitic role in the environment and because of the controversy of whether they should be considered Fungi

 To help clarify the fungal versus protistan controversy, we explored mode of nutrition for the obligate endoparasite, Rozella, in its host, Allomyces. Using serial section analysis and transmission electron microscopy, we demonstrated that Rozella phagocytizes its host  from within the host's cytoplasm, a protistan characteristic.  Three features served as topological markers for phagocytosis: (a) the mature host-parasite interface consisted of three membrane layers; (b) the parasite's and host's mitochondria were morphologically distinct; and (c) host mitochondria were recruited to the surface of the host-parasite interface. The parasite's phagocytic vacuoles consisted of three membranes and were lined by host mitochondria and other host organelles, which is exactly the arrangement if the vacuoles were formed by phagocytosis. With time, host organelles and the inner two membranes in the phagocytic vacuoles were broken down, leaving the phagocytic vacuolar membrane as a single layer initially originating from the parasite's plasma membrane. At the end of the process, no host cytoplasm remained, and the parasite used the host wall as a container as it cleaved posteriorly uniflagellate zoospores.

We reconstructed early infection stages of Rozella into its host to find how the parasite entered host cytoplasm without damaging the host plasma membrane and immediately killing the host it needed for survival. Parasite zoospores encysted on the surface of the host, penetrated the wall with an infection tube, discharged their protoplasts through the host wall, and invaginated the host plasma membrane, which then surrounded the protoplast and formed a compartment, retaining the parasite inside the host cytoplasm.  Thus, the host plasma membrane was not breached. The parasite enlarged within the host compartment, and when it filled-up the host compartment, the host membrane was replaced by a two-membrane layered cisterna, which expanded with the parasite, until phagocytosis began.

Understanding the process of host infection and nutrition in Rozella contributes to a better understanding of the evolution of nutrition in the Opisthosporidia lineage. Although Rozella and Aphelidea are both phagotrophic, they appear to do this from different positions in the host cells: Rozella from within host cytoplasm; Aphelidea from outside the host plasma membrane (the protoplast apparently being discharged between host cell wall and plasma membrane). In Microsporidia, viewed as evolutionary derived from within Cryptomycota, nutrition is osmotrophic, like that of Fungi. Because of the position of Opisthosporidia in relationship to the fungal root and its sister relationship to the nucleariids, these results support the hypothesis that the common shared ancestor of Opisthosporidia, nucleariids, and Fungi was a free-living phagotrophic organism. Osmotrophic nutrition and parasitism then would have evolved independently in the lineages leading to Fungi and to Microsporidia.

A second goal of the project was determining the monophyly of Rozella. From molecular phylogenetic analysis, we found that septate and nonseptate inducing species of Rozella were monophyletic, allowing us to reject the proposal for separate genera.

A third goal was the discovery of new species. Because parasites of algae are problematic in efforts to obtain high yields of plant material for biofuel production, our discovery of new species of Aphelidea infecting  green algae grown in open outdoor ponds for biofuel production is important. We formally described Amoeboaphelidium occidentale and Aphelidium desmodesmi. Because the host alga, Desmodesmus armatus, for A. desmodesmi is one of those rare green algae found associated with soft-tissue infection in humans, the new aphelid has potential application in host-controlled growth. One of the new Rozella species we described is of particular interest.  Rozella rhizoclosmatii (a parasite of a chytrid fungus) exhibited a novel mode of infection. The smaller parasite zoospores attached to the larger swimming host zoospores (essentially, parasite zoospores "hitch-hiked" and then encysted on host zoospores), targeting the host for infection.

Broader outcomes include up-to-date taxonomic summaries for Rozella, Aphelidiaceae, and the recently related genus Nucleophaga, which will make studying these groups more tractable. With the possibility that there are endoparasitic taxa currently classified among the Chytridiomycota that might phylogenetically place in Cryptomycota, we summarized the taxonomy of Plasmophagus and Dictyomorpha, suggesting additional exploration. Undergraduate students and one graduate student gained experience isolating chytrid and oomycete hosts of Rozella, increasing their appreciation for microbial diversity. This project generated fourteen articles and a website.
